page.title: 04St. Agnes: Thomas Tonkin
page.content: Born in 1678, Thomas Tonkin was the second son of Hugh and Frances Tonkin who lived at Trevaunance, St. Agnes. In 1696 he drove a mile-long leat from the tail of Pell adit - restoring the water level to eleven sets of stamps and a gaunt, grist mill. In 1699 he married Elisabeth Kempe and they had 8 children. He died in 1742. Tonkin played the "Squire" of the village, spending money he could ill- afford on the small harbour and quay at Trevaunance Cove, St. Agnes. Tonkin (described by H.L.Douch as "The neglected historian") wrote of St. Agnes "It has forty houses and a weekly market for all sorts of wares and victuals - except corn". He tried to obtain a patent for a market and two fairs yearly. This was granted but later revoked.
